title: Historical Stock Price Performance of Activision Blizzard Inc during Significant Market Events

content.text: During the dot-com bubble, which peaked in early 2000, the stock market experienced a significant rally followed by a crash. Activision Blizzard Inc, which was known as Activision at that time, saw its stock price rise from around $0.30 per share in 1999 to a peak of approximately $3.50 per share in February 2000. However, as the bubble burst, the stock price plummeted, reaching a low of around $0.40 per share by the end of 2000.

The global financial crisis, which originated from the subprime mortgage crisis in the United States, had a significant impact on the stock market. Activision Blizzard Inc, which was formed in 2008 through the merger of Activision and Vivendi Games, experienced a decline in its stock price during this period. From 2007 to early 2009, the stock price decreased from around $20 per share to approximately $7 per share.

The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a global economic downturn, and stock markets experienced a major crash in March 2020. Activision Blizzard Inc, as a video game company, benefited from increased demand for gaming during this period. Its stock price initially declined along with the broader market but quickly recovered and reached new all-time highs. From March 2020 to the present, the stock price rose from around $50 per share to over $100 per share.

Activision Blizzard Inc's stock price has also been influenced by other market events, such as product launches, earnings reports, and industry trends. These events can lead to both positive and negative movements in the stock price.

Activision Blizzard Inc's stock price has shown a varying performance during significant market events. It experienced a sharp decline during the dot-com bubble and the global financial crisis but performed well during the COVID-19 pandemic. Understanding the historical context of these events is essential for analyzing the stock's overall performance.

news.headline: UPDATE 1-US FTC sets date for internal arguments on Microsoft deal to buy Activision
news.summary: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission set a date on Wednesday for its internal judge to hear its arguments on why Microsoft should not be allowed to buy games maker Activision Blizzard for $69 billion.  While the U.S. challenge continues, most of the antitrust focus has been on London, where Britain's Competition and Markets Authority, which had balked at approving the deal, said this month that Activision's offer to sell its streaming rights to Ubisoft Entertainment "substantially addresses previous concerns."  Microsoft said it continued to plan to close the transaction on Oct. 18.

news.headline: Streaming will transform video games just like Netflix shook up TV, says Ubisoft
news.summary: Streaming will transform the video games industry just like Netflix revolutionised television and cinema, according to the head of Ubisoft, after the French company struck a transformational cloud-gaming deal with Microsoft.  Ubisoft, the creator of console franchises including Assassin’s Creed and Tom Clancy’s Rainbow Six, last month agreed to acquire streaming rights for Activision Blizzard’s portfolio of games as part of Microsoft’s bid to secure regulators’ approval for its $75bn takeover of Activision.  “When Netflix first said it was going to go into streaming, their shares fell a lot and they were widely criticised,” Ubisoft chief executive Yves Guillemot told the Financial Times.

news.headline: Microsoft’s Restructured Activision Deal Awaits UK Regulator’s Decision
news.summary: Microsoft Corporation's (NASDAQ:MSFT) restructured acquisition plan of Activision Blizzard (NASDAQ:NASDAQ:ATVI) for $69 billion is expected to receive a preliminary decision from the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) next week, according to a report from The Verge on Wednesday, September 20 2023. The final decision due by the regulator is set for October 18.

news.headline: UK minister rejects Microsoft criticism of decision to block Activision deal
news.summary: British business minister Kemi Badenoch said on Tuesday she did not agree with Microsoft President Brad Smith that the Competition and Market Authority's initial decision to block its purchase of videogame maker Activision was bad for Britain.  "Call of Duty" maker Activision Blizzard has since said it will sell its streaming rights in a fresh attempt to win approval from Britain's anti-trust regulator, the CMA, for its $69 billion sale to Microsoft.
